articles.title: Olivia Dean Helps Fans Get Money Back from Ticket Companies
articles.summary: Olivia Dean is a famous singer who spoke out against ticket companies like Ticketmaster and AXS. She said it was unfair that some people were selling tickets to her concerts for much more money than the original price. For example, tickets that should have cost around $70 were being sold for over $1,000. Olivia wrote a letter calling this practice disgusting and asked the companies to do better. As a result, Ticketmaster agreed to give some fans a refund for the extra money they paid and promised to limit high prices for future ticket sales. Olivia wants live music to be affordable for everyone, and she is happy that her actions are making a difference. This story shows how artists can stand up for their fans.

articles.title: How Lasers Break Apart Tiny Football Molecules
articles.summary: Scientists used special X-ray cameras to make movies of how strong lasers break apart a molecule called Buckminsterfullerene, which looks like a tiny soccer ball. This molecule is made of 60 carbon atoms. By shining intense laser light on it, they watched how the molecule changes and splits into pieces. This helps us learn how to control chemical reactions with light. The research was done by teams from Germany, Switzerland, the USA, and Japan using a big machine called the Linac Coherent Light Source. They found that at low laser power, the molecule expands first, and at high power, it breaks apart quickly. This work is important for understanding how atoms move in molecules.

articles.title: La Voix Joins Annie Musical Tour
articles.summary: La Voix, a famous drag queen from Buckinghamshire, is very excited to play Miss Hannigan in the Annie musical tour across the UK. The tour starts in May 2026 in Wimbledon and will visit cities like Birmingham, Manchester, and more. La Voix says Miss Hannigan is a loud and chaotic character, perfect for her. Other stars like Paul O'Grady have played this role before. La Voix had to leave Strictly Come Dancing because of an injury, but she is happy about her new role. The article shares her feelings and the tour details for fans to enjoy.

articles.title: Saving the Home of a Famous Song
articles.summary: Campaigners are working hard to save Ellisland Farm, a historic place in Scotland where Robert Burns wrote the famous song 'Auld Lang Syne'. They need to raise Â£12 million to fix the farm because it has problems like damp and decay. The farm is very old and important, and they want to make it a fun place for people to visit, with a museum and other attractions. A special film was made to show why the farm matters. The leaders of the trust, like Duncan Dornan and Joan McAlpine, believe this project will help the local economy and inspire everyone. They have already raised some money and plan to share more details next year.

articles.title: Elle Vosque Almost Wins Big Drag Race Show
articles.summary: Elle Vosque, a drag queen from Northern Ireland, came in second place on a TV show called Ru Paul's Drag Race UK. She was in the final with other queens, and the winner was Bones. Friends and fans watched the show together at a bar in Belfast to support her. This was Elle's first time performing outside of Northern Ireland. People like Trudy Scrumptious and The Only Sassie said they are very proud of Elle and think she shows the best of Belfast's drag scene. Drag is a fun way people dress up and perform to express themselves.

articles.title: A Fun Way to Recycle Teflon
articles.summary: Scientists have found a new way to recycle Teflon, a strong plastic used in non-stick pans and other items. Teflon is hard to break down and often ends up in landfills, which can harm the environment. But researchers from Newcastle University and the University of Birmingham discovered that by shaking Teflon with sodium metal at room temperature, they can turn it into useful materials like sodium fluoride, which is in toothpaste. This method is clean and doesn't use harmful chemicals, helping to reduce waste and protect our planet. It's exciting because it makes recycling easier and turns old Teflon into something new and valuable.
